facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1957, of the Election Tribunal, Ajmer, in Election Petition No. 2 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 31, 1957, of the Election Tribunal, Ajmer, in Election Petition No. 2 of 1956.

facts.text: Election Tribunal set aside the election of the appellant, Maulana Abdul Shakoor.

anchor.surface_text: from the order of the Election Tribunal dated January 31, 1957, setting aside the election of the appellant, Maulana Abdul Shakoor,

facts.text: Maulana Abdul Shakoor was elected to the Council of States by the Electoral College of Ajmer consisting of 30 members constituting the State Legislature of Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: Maulana Abdul Shakoor, who was elected to the Council of States by the Electoral College of Ajmer which companysisted of 30 members companystituting the State Legislature of Ajmer.

facts.text: Appellant received 19 votes as against 7 polled in favour of the other candidate who is respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: He received 19 votes as against 7 polled in favour of the other candidate who is respondent No. 1 in this appeal.

facts.text: Total number of valid votes polled was 26 and there were 3 invalid votes.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of valid votes polled was 26 and there were 3 invalid votes.

facts.text: Result of the election was published in the Official Gazette on March 31, 1957, declaring the election of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the election was published in the Official Gazette on March 31, 1957, declaring the election of the appellant.

facts.text: Unsuccessful candidate, respondent No. 1, filed election petition on May 2, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The unsuccessful candidate, the present first respondent, filed his election petition on May 2, 1956.

facts.text: Impugned election was held on March 22, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned election was held on March 22, 1956.

facts.text: Notification issued on February 17, 1956, nominations to be filed between February 28, 1956, and March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification issued on February 17, 1956, the numberinations for candidature were to be filed between February 28, 1956, and March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Date for scrutiny was March 5, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The date for scrutiny was March 5, 1956, and for the polling March 22, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant filed two nomination papers on February 28, 1956, and a third one on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed two numberination papers on February 28, 1956, and a third one on March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Respondent Rikhab Chand Jain filed his nomination papers on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Rikhab Chand Jain also filed his numberination papers on March 1, 1956.

facts.text: On March 5, 1956, respondent Rikhab Chand Jain raised objections to validity of appellant's nomination, main ground office of profit under Government.

anchor.surface_text: On March 5, 1956, the respondent Rikhab Chand Jain raised certain objections to the validity of the appellants numberination, the main ground being that the appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government.

facts.text: Returning Officer by order dated March 6, 1956, rejected two nomination papers of appellant filed on February 28, 1956, but accepted the third one of March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer by his order dated March 6, 1956, rejected the two numberination papers of the appellant filed on February 28, 1956, but accepted the third one, i.e., of March 1, 1956,

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Emergency Provisions Act, 1950 (XVII of 1950) in force up to February 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: because, according to that officer, under the provisions of Durgah Khwaja Saheb  Emeregency Provisions  Act, 1950  XVII of 1950  which was in force up to February 29, 1956,

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act XXXVI of 1955 came into force on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: but on the companying into force of the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act  XXXVI of 1955  on March 1, 1956, he numberlonger held such office under the Government.

facts.text: Respondent filed election petition on May 3, 1956 under s.81 Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On May 3, 1956, the respondent filed an election petition under s. 81 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951,

facts.text: Majority of Election Tribunal by order dated January 31, 1957 held that on March 1, 1956, appellant was holding office of profit under Government, nomination paper hit by Art.102(1)(a), set aside election, declared respondent elected.

anchor.surface_text: A majority of the Election Tribunal by their order dated January 31, 1957, held that on March 1, 1956, the appellant was holding an office of profit under the Government and therefore his numberination paper was hit by Art. 102 1  a  of the Constitution. They set aside his election and accepting the companytention as to thrown away votes declared the respondent elected.

facts.text: Chairman of Election Tribunal dissented, held on March 1, 1956 appellant no longer holding office of profit under Government, election valid.

anchor.surface_text: Disagreeing with the majority, the Chairman of the Election Tribunal held that on March 1, 1956, the appellant was numberlonger holding an office of profit under the Government, his numberination paper was rightly accepted and his election was valid

facts.text: Tribunal unanimously held two nomination papers of February 28, 1956 invalid as appellant held office of profit on that date.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the two numberination papers of the appellant dated February 28, 1956, were valid or number the Tribunal unanimously held them to be invalid on the ground that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government on that date.

facts.text: Argument proceeded on assumption that appellant held an office of profit.

anchor.surface_text: It may here be stated that the argument before us has proceeded on the assumption that the appellant held an office of profit.

facts.text: Appellant held appointment of manager (mohatmin) in Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari.

anchor.surface_text: The Madarsa Durgah Khwaja Saheb Akbari in which the appellant held the appointment of a manager  mohatmin  is a school

facts.text: On February 28, 1955, appellant given honorary appointment of mohatmin (manager) of the school by Administrator of Durgah Khwaja Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28, 1955, the appellant was given an honorary appointment of mohatmin  manager  of the school by the Administrator of Durgah Khwaja Saheb.

facts.text: From May 1955, appellant paid Rs. 100 per month described as salary or honorarium.

anchor.surface_text: But from May 1955 he was being paid Rs. 100 per month which has been variously described as salary and honorarium.

facts.text: Before 1951, school managed by Government of Nizam of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: Before 1951 it was managed and run by the Government of the Nizam of Hyderabad.

facts.text: In 1951, school taken over by Durgah Committee.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951 this school was taken over by the Durgah Committee.

facts.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act 1955 received assent of President on October 14, 1955, came into force on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Act of 1950 was replaced by the Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act  XXXVI of 1955  which, received the assent of the President on October 14, 1955, but came into force oil March 1, 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds appellant not holding office of profit under Government of India on March 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the majority of the Tribunal has erred in holding that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside order of majority of Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

holdings.text: The appellant was not holding an office of profit under the Government of India on March 1, 1956, and therefore Article 102(1)(a) of the Constitution does not apply to disqualify him.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances the majority of the Tribunal has erred in holding that the appellant held an office of profit under the Government and the opinion of the Chairman to the contrary lays down the correct position.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict textual interpretation of Art.102(1)(a) requires office directly under Government of India/State, not statutory body like Durgah Committee despite government appointment of members and oversight; appellant appointed by Committee, not removable directly by government, paid from endowment funds; distinguished from Art.58/66/191 which explicitly include controlled authorities.

holdings.text: The power of the Government to appoint/continue/revoke an office at discretion and payment from Government revenues are important factors to determine if an office is under the Government.

anchor.surface_text: The power of the Government to appoint a person to an office of profit or to continue him in that office or revoke his appointment at their discretion and payment from out of Government revenues are important factors in determining whether that person is holding an office of profit under the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multi-factor test applied; appellant fails as no direct government appointment, removal power, or payment from government revenues; payment from other source not decisive but relevant.

holdings.text: Servants of the statutory Durgah Committee do not hold office of profit under the Government merely because Committee members are appointed/removable by Government or bylaws require government approval.

anchor.surface_text: Merely because the Committee or the members of the Committee are removeable by the Government of India or the Committee can make bye-laws prescribing the duties and powers of its employees cannot in our opinion convert the servants of the Committee

holdings.reasoning_summary: Indirect control via appointment of committee members and oversight insufficient for 'under the Government'; Committee is independent body corporate with own powers under s.11 to appoint/dismiss servants.

holdings.text: Article 102(1)(a) and Art.191(1)(a) disqualify only for offices of profit directly under Government of India/State, unlike Art.58(2) and Art.66(4) which include offices under authorities subject to government control.

anchor.surface_text: A comparison of the different articles of the Constitution 58 2 , 66 4 , 102 1 a and 19 1 1 a dealing with membership of the State Legislatures shows in the case of members of the Legislatures unlike the case of the President and the Vice-President

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction based on deliberate difference in constitutional language; no extension of 'control' disqualification to legislators.

holdings.text: The election of the appellant was valid; the Tribunal majority erred in setting it aside; appeal allowed and Tribunal order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from finding that no disqualification under Art.102(1)(a); nomination valid.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide validity of nomination papers filed on February 28, 1956, or issue of thrown away votes.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to go into the question whether the two nomination papers filed by the appellant on February 28, 1956, were valid or not because if the nomination paper filed on March 1, 1956, is valid the question

holdings.reasoning_summary: March 1 nomination valid, so other issues moot.

holdings.text: Cited election cases and Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank are inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: A number of election cases reported in the Election Law Reports were cited before us but they were decided on their own facts and are of little assistance... Shivnandan Sharma v. The, Punjab National Bank Ltd. That was a case under the Industrial Disputes Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decided on own facts; different context (industrial disputes).

precedents.citation: Shivnandan Sharma v. The, Punjab National Bank Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then sought to fortify his sub. missions by relying on Shivnandan Sharma v. The, Punjab National Bank Ltd.  1 . That was a case under the Industrial Disputes Act and the question for decision was whether a cashier appointed by the Banks treasurer on behalf of the Bank and paid by the Bank was a servant of the Bank. It was held that he was.

precedents.case_name: Shivnandan Sharma v. Punjab National Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: if the master employs a servant and authorises him to employ a number of persons to do a particular job and to guarantee their fidelity and efficiency for cash consideration, the employees thus appointed by the servant would be, equally with the servant, servants of the master
precedents.cited_holding: a cashier appointed by the Bank's treasurer on behalf of the Bank and paid by the Bank was a servant of the Bank

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the election of the appellant has been wrongly set aside and we would allow the appeal and set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal's order setting aside appellant's election set aside; appellant's election valid
directions: set aside the order of the majority of the Tribunal
